review.title: MAP Estimation of Semi-Metric MRFs via Hierarchical Graph Cuts
review.abstract: We consider the task of obtaining the maximum a posteriori estimate of discrete pairwise random fields with arbitrary unary potentials and semimetric pairwise potentials. For this problem, we propose an accurate hierarchical move making strategy where each move is computed efficiently by solving an st-MINCUT problem. Unlike previous move making approaches, e.g. the widely used a-expansion algorithm, our method obtains the guarantees of the standard linear programming (LP) relaxation for the important special case of metric labeling. Unlike the existing LP relaxation solvers, e.g. interior-point algorithms or tree-reweighted message passing, our method is significantly faster as it uses only the efficient st-MINCUT algorithm in its design. Using both synthetic and real data experiments, we show that our technique outperforms several commonly used algorithms.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Markov Random Fields (MRFs) provide an expressive and intuitive framework for several important problems in artificial intelligence and machine learning. Given a number of random variables along with a neighborhood relationship defined through them, an MRF provides an accurate representation of the probability of each label (i.e. a specific mapping of labels to the variables) in terms of potentials defined through the cliques of random variables. Due to the central role of MRFs in various applications, algorithms that perform efficient and precise inference on them are highly desirable. An important and well-studied class of inferences called a posteriori maximum (MAP) estimation seeks the labeling with the maximum probability.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: The most commonly used semimetric labeling algorithms can be roughly divided into two categories: message forwarding and motion generation. Message forwarding algorithms attempt to minimize approximations to the free energy associated with MRF [10, 14, 15, 29, 34, 36]. Among them, the algorithms of [14, 15, 34] are closely related to the linear programming (LP) of semimetric labeling [7, 17, 25, 33]. Although message forwarding algorithms provide precise MAP estimates, in certain cases they can be computationally expensive [30]. Motion approaches refer to a large class of iterative algorithms that move from one label to another, ensuring that the probability of labeling never decreases. Movement space, i.e. the search space for the new label, is limited to a subrange of the original search space that can be efficiently explored. Typically, the CINUT-UT algorithm is used to investigate the motion space, for example.

sections.heading: 7 Discussion
sections.text: We presented an approach to the semi-metric labeling problem, which converts the given semimetric method into a mixture of r-HST metrics and solves each of the resulting problems with an efficient st-MINCUT-based algorithm. Our approach provides the guarantees for LP relaxation for the metric labeling problem. Together with the work of [5, 20], this provides further evidence for a link between randomized rounding techniques used with convex relaxations and move-making algorithms. We believe that further investigations in this direction would help to develop algorithms for more complex relaxations, such as [19, 28]. In practice, the results for both synthetic and real data experiments show that our method reduces the gap in performance between move-making algorithms and measurement-passiving approaches, especially in applications where the simple potentials do not specifically target the potential of the previously specified ARF (i.e. the good ARP pairing potentials).
